document.masterDocTitle: Revisionary study on European species of the Empria candidata complex (Hymenoptera, Symphyta, Tenthredinidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revisionary study on European species of the Empria candidata complex (Hymenoptera, Symphyta, Tenthredinidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Tenthredo candidata
Fallén, 1808
: 105
–106, ♀, type locality: Sweden .

Tenthredo (Allantus) repanda
Klug, 1816
: 77
–78, ♀, type locality: Botanical Garden in Berlin, Germany .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material examined
.
Tenthredo candidata
Fallén 1808
. Lectotype (designated by Heidemaa et Prous): female, UUZM . Labelled: ‘‘Uppsala Univ. Zool. Mus. Typsamlingen nr. 1940 b Hymenoptera

Fallén 1808

candidata (
Fallén, 1808
)
♀ M. HEIDEMAA & M. PROUS [white label, printed].

Tenthredo (Allantus) repanda
Klug, 1816
. Lectotype (here designated), ZMHB . Labelled: ‘‘ 13840 [white label, printed] // Kl. [white label, handwritten] // Repanda Kl. ♀ [white label, handwritten] // GBIF-GISHym 2387 [white label, printed] // Zool. Mus. Berlin [white label, handwritten] // Lectotypus
Tenthredo (Allantus) repanda
Klug, 1816
des. J. Macek 2014 [red label, printed]’’. Paralectotype , ZMHB . Labelled: ‘‘ 13840 [white label, printed] // GBIF- GISHym 2388 [white label, printed] // Zool. Mus. Berlin [white label, printed] // Paralectotypus
Tenthredo (Allantus) repanda
Klug, 1816
des. J. Macek 2014 [red label, printed]’’.

Three remaining females of the syntype series of
T. (A.) repanda
designated as paralectotypes ( PARALECTOTYPUS
Tenthredo (Allantus) repanda
Klug 1816
Des. J. Macek 2014
[red label, printed]) belong to
Empria magnicornis (Eversmann, 1864 )
(see below).

PLATE 1 .
Figs 1–3 . Types . 1 —
Tenthredo (Allantus) repanda
Klug, 1816
( lectotype , female): a—head (dorsal view); bhabitus (lateral view); c—habitus (dorsal view). 2 —
Tenthredo candidata
Fallén, 1808
( lectotype , female): a—head (dorsal view); b—habitus (lateral view); c—habitus (dorsal view). 3 —
T. magnicornis Eversmann, 1864
( type , male): a—head (frontal view); b—habitus (dorsal view); c—penis valve (incomplete, dorsal spine missing). Scale: habitus— 5 mm ; head— 1 mm ; penis valve—0.4 mm.

Empria candidata (
Fallén, 1808
)
: a—male, habitus (dorsal view); b—female (habitus, dorsal view); cmale (head, frontal view); d—head (female, dorsal view); e—mesosoma (female, dorsal view); f—penis valve; gmesepisternum. Scale: habitus— 5 mm ; head— 1 mm ; mesosoma + mesepisternum—1.5 mm; penis valve—0.4 mm.

PLATE 3 .
Figs. 5 .
Empria magnicornis (Eversmann, 1864 )
: a—male (habitus, dorsal view); b—female (habitus, dorsal view); c—male (head, frontal view); d—head (female, dorsal view); e—mesosoma (female, dorsal view); f—penis valve; g—mesepisternum. Scale: habitus— 5 mm ; head— 1 mm ; mesosoma + mesepisternum—1.5 mm; penis valve—0.4 mm.

PLATE 4 .
Figs. 6–7 . Larvae. 6 —
Empria magnicornis (Eversmann, 1864 )
: a—pale form; b—dark form. 7 —
E. candidata (
Fallén, 1808
)
. Scale: 10 mm .

Variability. The length of females varies between 6–8 mm , in males 5–7 mm ; two pale spots on clypeus in males separate or coalescent; in females the number of the pale paired patches on abdominal terga varies in shape, size and number from three to five, in males from two to three; in some male specimens the posterior patches becoming obliterated, or absent; in females two pale spots of variable size on mesepisternum, the anterior spot sometimes obliterated or enlarged and partly coalescent with posterior spot; the hind femora in females black with pale apices to pale with dark interior side.

Bionomics. Habitat: deciduous and mixed forests with birch, birch stands from colline to montane zone; flight period April to mid May; larval period from June to mid July. Host plants:
B. pendula
(
Lorenz & Kraus 1957
;
Taeger et al. 1998
),
Betula pubescens
(new record),
B. carpatica
(new record).
Empria candidata
often occurs syntopically with its close relative
E. magnicornis
.
Distribution. Palearctic; Sweden , Czech Republic , Germany (the present distribution pattern is based only on the data of the revised specimens).

Discussion. The species name has been applied according to the female lectotype specimen as selected and designated by
Heidemaa & Prous (Prous et al. 2011 )
. The revised type series of five female specimens of
Tenthredo (Allantus) repanda ,
a junior synonym of
E. candidata
, is composed of two distinct species. Two specimens including the lectotype with handwritten label proved to be conspecific with
E. candidata
, whilst the three remaining specimens belong to the here revalidated
Empria magnicornis
(see below). The specimen bearing Klug´s original handwritten label was selected and designated lectotype of
Tenthredo ( Allantus) repanda
, thus maintaining
Thomson´s ( 1870 )
synonymy of this nominal taxon with
E. candidata
. Nevertheless, the correct association of the males as given in some later publications (
Conde 1934
;
Benson 1938
, 1952 ) is impossible to check, due to the vague diagnosis. An exception is
Prous et al. ( 2011 )
, where the illustrated penis valve undoubtedly belongs to
E. magnicornis
. Larvae as described and illustrated by
Brischke ( 1883 )
,
Lorenz & Kraus ( 1957 )
and Verzhutskii ( 1966 ) agree more with
Empria magnicornis
than
E. candidata .
